ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New NEAT/HyperNEAT/NS Software Catalog
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks Colin. Does anyone on this list know CMA-ES enough to know if it is doing something equivalent to trying to determine appropriate per-parameter mutation

Thanks Colin. Does anyone on this list know CMA-ES enough to know if it is =
doing something equivalent to trying to determine appropriate per-parameter=
 mutation step sizes dynamically?


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Pro=
fessor, Computer Science
Director, Evolving Artificial Intelligence Lab <ht=
tp://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.co=
m

> On May 7, 2015, at 4:16 PM, Colin Green colin.green1@... [neat] =
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> On 7 May 2015 at 21:20, kstanley@...=
as.edu [neat]
> <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> >
> > I'm curious, how do y=
ou think evolution with a random uniform mutation distribution
> > compares=
 to RMS-Prop or regular SGD? Would it tend to act like GD and kind of slow
=
> > down on shallow gradient dimensions, or would it be more even-handed li=
ke
> > RMS-Prop, or perhaps something in the middle?
> 
> Random mutation d=
oesn't have that specifc flaw of GD that RMSProp is
> solving, namely that =
GD is really slow escaping locations with very
> low gradient. Random searc=
h ignores the gradient so can't get stuck in
> that way.
> 
> RMSProp doesn=
't ignore the gradient, but it does sort of ignore its
> /magnitude/ (but n=
ot the sign). I say 'sort of' because fluctuations
> in the magnitude do af=
fect the path it takes.
> 
> Random search will of course travel in the wro=
ng direction 50% of the
> time (w.r.t. a given axis), and it has the same i=
ssues around choosing
> a good step size, i.e. we have to experimentaly fin=
d good weight
> mutation deltas. Good step sizes are not discovered automat=
ically.
> 
> Finally, random search has no equivalent of RMSProp's 'per var=
iable'
> learning rate. Hence it has that problem of trying to use a step s=
ize
> that is good for all of the variables, but the success of RMSProp
> s=
uggests that the 'one step size fits all' approach is problematic.
> 
> Col=
in
> 


--Apple-Mail=_90573A5C-D09D-4C28-82DE-7B9E549DE4EE

<span style=3D"display:none" cla=
ss=3D""> </span>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text" class=3D""><p class=3D""=
>On 7 May 2015 at 21:20, <a href=3D"mailto:kstanley@..." class=3D=
"">kstanley@...</a> [neat]<br class=3D"">
<<a href=3D"mailto:n=
eat@yahoogroups.com" class=3D"">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>> wrote:<br clas=
s=3D"">
><br class=3D"">
> I'm curious, how do you think evolution wi=
th a random uniform mutation distribution<br class=3D"">
> compares to R=
MS-Prop or regular SGD?  Would it tend to act like GD and kind of slow<br c=
lass=3D"">
> down on shallow gradient dimensions, or would it be more ev=
en-handed like<br class=3D"">
> RMS-Prop, or perhaps something in the mi=
ddle?<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Random mutation doesn't have that spec=
ifc flaw of GD that RMSProp is<br class=3D"">
solving, namely that GD is re=
ally slow escaping locations with very<br class=3D"">
low gradient. Random =
search ignores the gradient so can't get stuck in<br class=3D"">
that way.<=
br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
RMSProp doesn't ignore the gradient, but it =
does sort of ignore its<br class=3D"">
/magnitude/ (but not the sign). I sa=
y 'sort of' because fluctuations<br class=3D"">
in the magnitude do affect =
the path it takes.<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Random search will of cou=
rse travel in the wrong direction 50% of the<br class=3D"">
time (w.r.t. a =
given axis), and it has the same issues around choosing<br class=3D"">
a go=
od step size, i.e. we have to experimentaly find good weight<br class=3D"">=

mutation deltas. Good step sizes are not discovered automatically.<br clas=
s=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Finally, random search has no equivalent of RMSProp=
's 'per variable'<br class=3D"">
learning rate. Hence it has that problem o=
f trying to use a step size<br class=3D"">
that is good for all of the vari=
ables, but the success of RMSProp<br class=3D"">
suggests that the 'one ste=
p size fits all' approach is problematic.<br class=3D"">
<br class=3D"">
Co=
lin<br class=3D"">
</p>

    </div>

mail -->
